arm_group.arm_group_label: grupo TENS com frequência de 100 Hz
arm_group.description: TENS application of high frequency (100 Hz, 100 μs)

arm_group.arm_group_label: grupo TENS com frequência de 4 Hz
arm_group.description: Application of low-frequency TENS (4 Hz, 100 μs)

brief_summary.textblock:
The aim of the study was to evaluate the analgesic effect of transcutaneous electrical nerve
      stimulation High (100 Hz) and low (4 Hz) frequency in postpartum pain after cesarean
      section.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Modulation of TENS in Pain After Cesarean Section

detailed_description.textblock:
Mothers were randomly divided into three groups (G100, G4 and placebo (GP) - appliance off)
      and evaluated by NRS (numeric rating scale) before, immediately after application of TENS,
      and every 20 minutes until he was one hour after the application of electroanalgesia, to
      verify its effectiveness over time.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  aged 18 years

          -  present pain at the site of surgical incision less than three according to Category
             Numerical Scale (NRS)

          -  literate oriented as to time and space

          -  with spinal anesthesia before surgery

          -  incision pfannenstiel type with absence of genitourinary pathology

          -  primiparous or multiparous

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  patients with abnormal sensitivity to clinical examination

          -  demyelinating diseases

          -  spinal cord injury

          -  hemorrhage

          -  infection

          -  fever

          -  anesthetic complications

          -  hypertension, mammary, intolerance, irritation or strong discomfort at the injection
             site caused by TENS

arm_group_label: grupo TENS com frequência de 100 Hz
grupo TENS com frequência de 4 Hz

facility.name: Santa Casa de Misericordia Hospital and State Hospital Dirceu Arco Verde

clinical_study.official_title: Hypoalgesic Effect of TENS Modulation in Post-Cesarean Pain: A Clinical Trial Controlled and Randomized.
